docs.lead_paragraph: Audrey Jennings has seen her social life cut in half since minor cognitive impairment and balance problems were diagnosed three years ago in her husband, Ken. It's not just the time she spends caring for him at their new condominium in Annapolis, Md., she says. His diminished conversational skills have meant fewer bridge games and less dining out and mixing with friends. But Mrs. Jennings, 68, says she has found a lifeline -- an adult day program, sometimes called adult day care, that provides her the opportunity for outside social interaction while her husband is being supervised in a safe environment.

headline.main: A Little-Known Reprieve From Providing Care

docs.lead_paragraph: WANTED: Exceptionally tidy people with attractive furniture to live in nice houses for low, low rent. Must not mind the hassles of frequent relocation, such as bubble-wrapping breakables, filing change-of-address forms and dealing with cable and Internet service providers. Must be willing to open home to strangers on short notice and to keep sink free of dirty dishes. It may not be for everyone. But Rick and Jennifer Mertes have it down to a science. The couple and their 20-month-old son, Cooper, have moved three times in just over a year, packing their belongings into several U-Haul trucks. Mr. Mertes, who works from home as a business consultant, now has a contact high up at the telephone company, whom he calls directly when it is that time again.
docs.abstract: Sellers of luxury homes increasingly engage 'home managers' to live in them at modest rent, to give potential buyers look at furnished, decorated rooms; photos (M)

headline.main: Living Large, But on the Fly

docs.lead_paragraph: FROM the front porch of Gregg and Genie Burch's three-story log cabin, which sits at 9,000 feet near the tiny town of Ward, there are unobstructed Rocky Mountain views, including two of Colorado's tallest peaks. That vista allowed the Burches a front-row seat to last summer's Big Elk fire near Estes Park, which burned 4,400 acres and cost three lives. The fire was 10 miles to the north, and Mrs. Burch watched it obsessively, sitting on the top floor of their house with a telescope. It was a close-enough encounter for the Burches to recognize the dangers of their living on 40 acres on Burnt Mountain (so named for its cone of volcanic rock, not for the fire that swept over it in the 1940's).
docs.abstract: Some Colorado landowners, taking cue from spate of fires in West, are implementing wildfire mitigation; practice involves cutting down dead trees and those too close to one another and to houses, removing low branches from remaining trees and clearing brush, and planting aspens, which hold moisture better and do not produce flammable resin; mitigation is becoming more common as people move to higher risk wooded areas, slowly changing landscape and creating sun-filled meadows and stands of well-spaced healthy trees; photos (L)

headline.main: Sacrificing the Trees To Save the House

docs.lead_paragraph: THE silver's missing and the police are wondering: Was it the guests? Burglars hit two historic houses in the Hudson Valley last week, making off with more than $100,000 in silver and parlor knickknacks. Sometime on Jan. 27 or 28, Wilderstein, the 19th-century mansion in Rhinebeck that was once the home of Daisy Suckley, Franklin Delano Roosevelt's distant cousin and frequent companion, was broken into. A sterling silver trophy and a sterling coffee service were taken, along with a bronze Tiffany lamp and several other items, together valued at more than $50,000.
docs.abstract: Burglars hit Wilderstein, 19th-century mansion in Rhinebeck, NY, and Edgewater mansion in Barrytown, making off with more than $100,000 in silver and parlor knickknacks; two cases are thought to be related; photo (M)

headline.main: Bits of History Are Stolen at Mansions

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court hears arguments on Tuesday in a case that gives it a chance to stop political groups and corporations from gouging a major hole in federal campaign finance law. The case revolves around ''Hillary: The Movie,'' an anti-Hillary Rodham Clinton film made before the 2008 election. A lower federal court ruled that the film falls under federal law restricting the airing of attack ads. The Supreme Court should affirm that ruling. ''Hillary: The Movie'' was produced by Citizens United, a conservative nonprofit corporation. The film is full of express arguments that Mrs. Clinton would not be a suitable president or commander in chief.
docs.abstract: Editorial urges Supreme Court to uphold ruling that anti-Hillary Clinton film made by conservative group Citizens United before 2008 election falls under federal law restricting corporate financing of political ads; maintains that affirming lower court decision will block political groups and corporations from creating loophole in federal campaign finance law that would allow corporate money to flood partisan politics
docs.snippet: If Citizens United prevails in its Supreme Court case, it would allow corporate money to flood into partisan politics in ways it has not in decades....

docs.lead_paragraph: EVEN before she made her first movie, Rachel Griffiths's face was famous. She first realized this back home in Australia while sitting in a Melbourne movie house watching Martin Scorsese's 1991 remake of the thriller ''Cape Fear.'' In it, Robert De Niro's oily convict stalks a teen-ager played by Juliette Lewis, who has the same high forehead as Ms. Griffiths, as well as the same full mouth, large eyes and short dark hair. Being presented with so many similarities writ so very large was almost too much for Ms. Griffiths. ''When she came on the screen, I turned to my best friend and we both went, 'This is scary,' '' said Ms. Griffiths, who, had she felt like it, could have held an impromptu autograph-signing session afterward. ''When I walked out of the theater, everybody was just staring at me.''
docs.abstract: Profile of and interview with Australian actress Rachel Griffiths, who has garnered best supporting actress nomination for movie Hilary and Jackie; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton was elected senator from New York last night, ending a 16-month spectacle of a campaign and ensuring that a Clinton will remain in Washington after her husband, the president, leaves the White House on Jan. 20.
docs.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton is elected senator from New York, soundly defeating four-term Republican incumbent Repr Rick A Lazio; gets 55% of vote; Lazio gets 43%; Mrs Clinton is congratulated by Lazio, who urges New Yorkers in concession speech to move forward together; Clinton expresses profound gratitude to voters; pledges to reach across party lines to bring progress for all New York families; is first woman to be elected senator from New York, in latest turn in improbable if wrenching public life that has captivated and polarized much of nation for past eight years; victory ends perhaps most unusual political contest in state since 1964, when outsider Robert F Kennedy defeated incumbent Republican Kenneth B Keating; Clinton's 16-month quest and factors contributing to her success discussed; photos; maps; tally (M)

headline.main: Big Victory for First Lady in Contest With Lazio
